title: Westpac's refund costs approach $1b
text:
Alongside the increased refund costs, Westpac unveiled a fresh $36 million after-tax charge for its continuing reset of the wealth division. The extra costs bring that initiative's expenses for the financial year to $172 million after tax.

The combined costs will see Westpac bleed $1.1 billion after tax in its cash earnings for the 2019 financial year.

Shares in Westpac closed 0.2 of a percentage point lower to $28.91 on Wednesday.

"As part of our 'get it right put it right' initiative, we are determined to fix these issues and stop these errors occurring," said Mr Hartzer.

"We will continue to review our products and services to ensure they deliver the right outcomes for customers, and if necessary, make further provisions."

Evans and Partner's analyst Matthew Wilson said Westpac, along with the rest of the sector, was now playing catch-up to the $1.2 billion the National Australia Bank provisioned for compensation in October.

"Whilst issues in wealth have dominated recent conduct provisions, as ANZ’s announcement (8 October, 2019) demonstrates, banking-related issues will likely grow," Mr Wilson said.

Advertisement

"[Westpac] needs active capital management – raise capital ... and cut the dividend."

AUSTRAC penalties loom

In the same release, the bank also warned shareholders of the potential outcome of the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre's enquiry into its activities.

AUSTRAC is investigating the bank's failure to report a significant number of International Funds Transfer instructions as required under anti-money laundering laws.

"Any enforcement action against Westpac may include civil penalty proceedings and result in the payment of a significant financial penalty," said Westpac.

The bank said it was unable to make a reliable estimate of the costs related to any AUSTRAC penalty or court action at this time.

"AUSTRAC has issued a number of detailed statutory notices over the last year requiring information relating to the Group's processes, procedures and oversight," Westpac said.

"Westpac has not yet received an indication from AUSTRAC about the nature of any enforcement action it may take. The Group is continuing to work with AUSTRAC in relation to these matters."

"Updated significant developments, contingent liabilities and associated risk factors will be included in Westpac's 2019 Annual Report."

Westpac will release its full-year financial results on November 4.

The other major banks have also been announcing fresh refunds in recent weeks. ANZ said a $651 million remediation bill would hit its half-year profits in early October.

Meanwhile, the National Australia Bank set aside an extra $1.2 billion over dubious insurance and financial advice practices at a similar time.

Commonwealth Bank has remediated $2.2 billion to customers over the past financial year.
description: The bank's customer remediation costs are primed to poke a $958 million hole in its cash earnings after it announced a new set of refunds late on Wednesday.
